topic.title: Structural signs and conventions

body.p: Structural signs are used to mark up morphological properties of a lexical entry and changes caused by inflections of words in the texts.

row.entry: All word, including suffix pronouns, are seperated by space.

body.p: Only morphological prefixes are allowed to be marked by the structure sign (‚Äú:‚Äù). Do not mark any prefix of word formation.

Suffixes are to be marked consistently by ‚Äú=‚Äù. Note the space between a word and ‚Äú=‚Äù. Lexically bound suffixes are also to be marked by ‚Äú=‚Äù to declare the suffix as included in the word (e.g. personal names), but are used without space.

Morphological endings are to be marked by a dot ‚Äú.‚Äù (e.g. numerus endings, inflective infix/affix), endings of word formations by a comma ‚Äú,‚Äù (e.g. feminin ending). Endings of proper names have to be written at the end of the full name, no matter if a name consists of compound words and/or suffixes.
NOTE: The feminin ending .t is marked by a comma (","), if the word is noun. The ending of adjectives is treated as morphological endings and thus marked by a dot ("."), e.g. nb,t nfr.t.

row.entry: ·∏™pr-·∏ès=f (he who came into being of himself)

body.p: Plural and dual endings are morphological endings and thus marked by a dot ("."). Phonetically written endings are transliterated as ".w", ".wj", ".wt" and ".tj" respectively. Strokes and other ideographic writings of number are represendted by either ".pl" or ".du". In case there is a phonetic and ideographic writing, both are represented in the transliteration, e.g. ".w.pl." or ".tj.du".
Dots and commas are combined if both morphological and inflectional endings appear in one word,e.g.:

Strokes and other ideographic writing are only represented by .pl and .du, respectively, if they mark "real" plurals or duals. If written in collectiva, they are treated as determinatives and are thus not transliterated, e.g.:
Proper names are written with an intial capital, also when they appear within a compound word.
Cartouches "ìçπ ... ìç∫", Serekhs "ìâò ... ìäÇ" and enclosures of places names "ìäÜ ... ìäá" etc. are treated as determintives and are thus not represented in the transliteration.

Verse points are represented in the transliteration via the appropriate signs (see Keyboard layout). There has to be a space before and after the verse point. Verse points are not represented in the hieroglyphical encoding.
